text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
in this video you'll see how to improve
security and enable auditing by
monitoring Windows user logins on your
Amazon Elastic Compute cloud or ec2
instances using cloud watch logs in
sites before you can monitor windows
logins using cloud watch you'll need to
first ensure security log data from any
windows instances is being collected to
get started from the AWS management
console let's navigate to the ec2
dashboard
can see we currently have three windows
instances running let's connect to the
first one this instance has already been
configured with the Amazon CloudWatch
agent so let's run the AWS cloud watch
agent configuration manager to configure
cloud watch agent to transmit Windows
security event logs continue through the
configuration manager wizard for now
let's skip ahead to the relevant command
prompts
when prompted whether to specify
additional windows event logs to monitor
select yes and then type in security
continue through the configuration
manager wizard for the log group name
let's call it Windows security logs now
proceed through the rest of the wizard
to store this configuration in the
parameter store
the configuration is now saved in the
parameter store let's disconnect from
the windows instance and navigate to AWS
Systems Manager to take a look at the
parameters store reviewing the
configuration we just created you can
see that it will collect both system and
security event logs from Windows
instances you can now apply this
configuration to your instances to begin
collecting Windows security logs in
cloud watch
next let's connect to the first Windows
instance again and open the Event Viewer
to review the security logs that are now
being collected
as you can see the security logs can
contain many different events let's
filter the list using an event ID that
shows only logon events
in the details pane you can see a
summary of the information that is being
transmitted to cloud watch for
monitoring such as the user name and
domain name
now let's disconnect from the instance
and open the cloud watch management
console
Amazon CloudWatch lets you collect
metrics and logs from your Amazon
Elastic Compute cloud instances and
provide measurable and actionable data
about system performance security events
and more
here you can see the different law
groups you've created including the
windows security logs group we created
earlier
looking inside the group we can see the
log streams for our three windows
instances and drilling down we can see
all the events being recorded for this
stream
cloud watch logs insights allows you to
quickly search and analyze your log data
using simple but powerful queries for
example you can select the windows
security logs group and run a query that
looks for logon events and displays the
username logon type and logon process
name for those events here you can see
the results including a visualization of
all the logon events that have occurred
you can also capture logon events for
machines that have been joined to an
Active Directory service hosted in AWS
as you can see we've added a fourth
windows instance that's been joined to a
domain hosted in AWS directory service
let's see how you can enable logging for
this directory first navigate to
directory service and select the
directory
scroll down and open the networking and
Security tab here you can enable log
forwarding
select choose an existing CloudWatch law
group make sure the windows security
logs group is selected and then enable
log forwarding
now let's return to cloud watch and run
the logon query again you can see that
the query results now contain events
from the joined Active Directory
instance it's easy to adjust the cloud
watch logs insights query to narrow your
search to actual user logins for example
if you know that some system user
accounts contain a certain character
such as a dollar sign you can add a
filter to the query to remove those
results
that's better however scrolling through
the results you can still see a few
system user logins
another filter to remove those logins
from the results as well
now when you run the query you can see
that the results include only actual
user login events
you've just seen how to improve security
and enable auditing by monitoring
windows user logins on your Amazon ec2
instances using cloud watch logs
insights thanks for watching now it's
your turn to try
